awd_titl_txt: 3D ImPACT: Integrated Project Approach to College Teaching
awd_abstract_narration:
Eastern Iowa Community College is meeting a need for highly trained technicians in additive manufacturing (AM) by developing AM content across  a set of programs as well as adopting multidisciplinary project-based instruction within courses. Faculty will collaborate with industry to develop AM content for welding, computer numeric control machining, mechanical design technology, logistics, information technology, and engineering technology. Incorporating problem-based instruction will promote students working together as well as developing critical thinking skills. A professional development webinar for high school and community college faculty will also be developed. Advanced manufacturing is Iowa's largest industry contributing $28 billion to the state's economy, representing 18% of Iowa's GDP and representing 13.5% of Iowa's employment.  Most growth is in cutting edge applications of big data, the Internet of Things, bio-based products, advanced materials, AM and electronic design. Broad incorporation of additive manufacturing content within the programs will result in increased skilled workers in advanced manufacturing, and the use of the integrated project-based learning method will result in workers with increased critical thinking and problem solving skills.

The goal of the Integrated Project Approach to College Teaching (3D ImPACT) project is to increase the number of skilled workers in AM through curriculum development; an integrated, project-based capstone course; and professional development for faculty. Activities include 1) collaborating with business and industry to conduct a Job Task Analyses and develop AM curriculum; 2) using the Digital Manufacturing and Design Innovation Institute training programs; 3) developing a project-based capstone course to allow students from different programs to work together to improve learning, performance and industry skill acquisition; 4) providing professional development for college and high school faculty; and 5) developing a project website. In addition, the project will help advance understanding of the circumstances under which integrated project-based learning methods will increase critical thinking and problem solving skills in a diverse workforce.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Eastern Iowa Community Colleges Blong Technolgoy Center

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The 3D ImPACT: Integrated Project Approach to College Teaching, DUE 1600143, integrated multidisciplinary, project-based teaching of Additive Manufacturing. This project was conducted at the Eastern Iowa Community Colleges John T. Blong Technology Center.

Notable outcomes are demonstrations and hand-on teaching to over 5,100 individuals through meetings, presentations, conferences, and manufacturing festivals regarding additive manufacturing industry.  These efforts have proven successful at showing the capabilities of additive manufacturing in throughout industry. Presentations have been created as to how additive manufacturing can be incorporated into a number of advanced manufacturing arenas.  These include Computer Numerical Control Machining, Welding, Supply Chain and Logistics, Mechanical Design, and Engineering Technology. Two courses have been developed as part of this project. 

The first being titled Introduction to 3D Printing.  This course introduces students to historical factors that have helped shape manufacturing over centuries. Students address the current and emerging 3D printing applications and describe advantages and limitations of each technology. Students evaluate real-life scenarios and make possible recommendations for the appropriate 3D printing technology from a time and cost saving viewpoint based on product requirements. A major emphasis is placed on discussion of the economic implications of 3D printing which will include impact on business startup and implications on supply chain as well. There is a hands on component of this class. Students will be required to download and print models, as well as create a 3D models, process, and print.

The second is Introduction to 3D Scanning.  This course introduces students to the use of various 3D scanners to scan parts or artifacts that are geometric and organic freeform in shape. These scans can then be imported to a Computer Aided Design (CAD) package in order to create intelligent models. Students will use hand held and stationary scanners to scan larger objects and objects that may be remotely located. These scans will also be imported into software and processed for modeling or printing.

These courses offer online and hands-on components. Videos related to additive manufacturing have been created and shared through YouTube channel 3d ImPACT.

Through the work on the 3D Impact project it was determined to that revisions to our current programming was needed.  A new offering of an Additive Manufacturing Certificate has been created to meet the demands of Advanced Manufacturing and our region.

 


Last Modified: 11/22/2021
Modified by: Jeffrey D Rose
